accessibilityNotes: Gippsland Lakes Coastal Park is located in East Gippsland. The western section of the park is accessible by a sealed road via Seaspray and Golden Beach. Paradise Beach Campground is located in campgrounds along Shoreline Drive.

Accessible only by boat, Bunga Arm was formed over many thousands of years when sand, deposited by the sea, built up between the original bay (now Lake Victoria) and the ocean. Approximately 250 metres divides the tranquil waters of Bunga Arm from the pounding surf of Bass Strait - and you can stay at one of the seven boat-based bush campsites located there. If you don’t have your own boat to access Bunga Arm, you can hire one at one of the lakeside towns.
dogPolicy: Pack your four-legged friend for dog-friendly car-based camping at Paradise Beach in Gippsland Lakes Coastal Park, west of Loch Sport.
Escape to Paradise Beach on the western side of Gippsland Lakes Coastal Park for a dog-friendly coastal stay.

name: Faithfull Hut, Alpine National Park

dogPolicy: Pineapple flat, also located on the banks of the King River, offers further camping and recreation opportunities for 4WDs within the King Valley. Please note this is not a designated horse camping area and dogs are prohibited in the Alpine National Park.

Take a drive with the whole family to Cobbler Lake Hut located on the breath taking Cobbler Lake. From there, undertake a challenging hike to the summit of Mt Cobbler and admire stunning views of the surrounding mountain peaks. Please note dogs are not permitted within the Alpine National Park and always ensure you check road conditions prior to undertaking your trip.

name: Forges Bend, Yarrawonga R.P
Bindaree Flat Camping Area, Alpine National Park

accessibilityNotes: Please note access to this campsite is accessible by 4WD only and requires river crossings. Weather in the Victorian High Country can be unpredictable and may change at any time. Ensure you check the weather prior to undertaking your trip as the Howqua River can rise quickly after heavy rain and may be unsafe to cross. Call the local Parks Victoria office on 13 19 63 or check the website to gain an understanding of current track conditions.
dogPolicy: Dogs are strictly prohibited throughout the Alpine National Park.
Assistance dogs are welcome in Parks Victoria parks and reserves. Entry requirements apply for parks and reserves that are usually dog prohibited, such as national parks.

dogPolicy: Pineapple flat, also located on the banks of the King River, offers further camping and recreation opportunities for 4WDs within the King Valley. Please note this is not a designated horse camping area and dogs are prohibited in the Alpine National Park.

Take a drive with the whole family to Cobbler Lake Hut located on the breath taking Cobbler Lake. From there, undertake a challenging hike to the summit of Mt Cobbler and admire stunning views of the surrounding mountain peaks. Please note dogs are not permitted within the Alpine National Park and always ensure you check road conditions prior to undertaking your trip.

accessibilityNotes: Gippsland Lakes Coastal Park is located in East Gippsland. The western section of the park is accessible by a sealed road via Seaspray and Golden Beach. Paradise Beach Campground is located in campgrounds along Shoreline Drive.

Accessible only by boat, Bunga Arm was formed over many thousands of years when sand, deposited by the sea, built up between the original bay (now Lake Victoria) and the ocean. Approximately 250 metres divides the tranquil waters of Bunga Arm from the pounding surf of Bass Strait - and you can stay at one of the seven boat-based bush campsites located there. If you don’t have your own boat to access Bunga Arm, you can hire one at one of the lakeside towns.
dogPolicy: Pack your four-legged friend for dog-friendly car-based camping at Paradise Beach in Gippsland Lakes Coastal Park, west of Loch Sport.

name: Upper Howqua Picnic Area, Alpine National Park

accessibilityNotes: Please note access to this campsite is accessible by 2WD depending on river levels. The trailhead carpark does not require river to be crossed. Weather in the Victorian High Country can be unpredictable and may change at any time. Ensure you check the weather prior to undertaking your trip as the Howqua River can rise quickly after heavy rain and may be unsafe to cross. Call the local Parks Victoria office on 13 19 63 or check the website to gain an understanding of current track conditions.

Upper Howqua Camping Area is located just over 2 hours’ drive from Mansfield. Take the Mt Buller Road east and enter via Howqua Hills (4WD only). Or continue to Mirrimbah and head in via Circuit Road (2WD accessible). Please note these roads are seasonally closed.
dogPolicy: Dogs are strictly prohibited throughout the Alpine National Park.

accessibilityNotes: Campground facilities include non-flush toilets, fireplaces, picnic tables and non-potable water. The campground is accessible by 2WD between May and November, 4WD may be required between December and April due to possible dry sandy track conditions.

Forest North Campground is north of the river and is accessed from Wanwin Road. The campground is usually accessible for 2WDs however in summer and extended dry periods the access track may become sandy and require a 4WD.

name: _Not Attached to a Site

accessibilityNotes: Visiting a park can be more of a challenge for people with disabilities, however, in Victoria there are a wide range of facilities to help people of all abilities enjoy our wonderful parks around the state. Parks Victoria provides a range of a equipment, including all-terrain and beach wheelchairs, facilities, accommodation and accessibility information and programs to help you plan and enjoy your visit to Victoria's parks.
dogPolicy: Assistance dogs are welcome in Parks Victoria parks and reserves. [Entry requirements apply](https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/get-into-nature/all-abilities-access/assistance-dogs)for parks and reserves that are usually dog prohibited, such as national parks.
